name: DietCodes
title: Diet Codes
description: Codes that can be used to indicate the type of food being ordered for a patient. This value set is provided as a suggestive example. It includes codes from [SNOMED CT](http://snomed.info/sct) where concept is-a 182922004 (Dietary regime (regime/therapy))
copyright: This resource includes content from SNOMED Clinical Terms® (SNOMED CT®) which is copyright of the International Health Terminology Standards Development Organisation (IHTSDO). Implementers of these specifications must have the appropriate SNOMED CT Affiliate license - for more information contact http://www.snomed.org/snomed-ct/get-snomed-ct or info@snomed.org

contains.display: CHILD-1 - Cardiovascular Health Integrated Lifestyle Diet

designation.value: CHILD-1 - Cardiovascular Health Integrated Lifestyle Diet

contains.display: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet (regime/therapy)

designation.value: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet (regime/therapy)
Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet
Increase or decrease in carbohydrate content of the diet.

A meal plan that offers comparable carbohydrate content from day to day at all meals and snacks. Not based on a set number of calories; intended to meet individuals' nutritional needs and facilitate improved metabolic control.
Increase or decrease in galactose content of the diet.
Increase or decrease in cholesterol content of the diet. (Source: Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics Nutrition Informatics Committee 2013)

contains.display: Diet modified for specific foods or ingredients (regime/therapy)

designation.value: Diet modified for specific foods or ingredients (regime/therapy)
Diet modified for specific foods or ingredients
Food or ingredient specific diet modifications indicated for an individual based on assessed food and nutrient needs to optimize health.
Increase or decrease in energy content of the diet.
Increase or decrease in fat content of the diet.
Increase or decrease in fiber content of the diet.
A diet composed of foods and/or fluids which are in a liquid state.
Foods and liquids that are transparent and liquid at body temperature.
Foods and liquids consistent with the clear liquid diet with the addition of milk and small amounts of fiber.
A diet which meets current professional recommendations of a healthy eating pattern.
Increase or decrease in mineral content of the diet. Treatment for conditions resulting from inadequate or excessive mineral intake.
Increase or decrease in protein content of the diet.
Alter the consistency of foods to optimize chewing and swallowing. (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).
Increase or decrease in vitamin content of the diet. Treatment for conditions resulting from inadequate or excessive vitamin intake.
Increase or decrease in lactose content of the diet.
Decrease in lactose content of the diet compared to the assessed baseline intake of lactose for the individual.

contains.display: Dietary liquid consistency - nectar thick liquid (regime/therapy)

designation.value: Dietary liquid consistency - nectar thick liquid (regime/therapy)
Dietary liquid consistency - nectar thick liquid
Liquids included in the diet are provided at a viscosity of 51-350 centipoise (cP). (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).

contains.display: Dietary liquid consistency - honey thick liquid (regime/therapy)

designation.value: Dietary liquid consistency - honey thick liquid (regime/therapy)
Dietary liquid consistency - honey thick liquid
Liquids included in the diet are provided at a viscosity of 351-1750 centipoise (cP). (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).

contains.display: Dietary liquid consistency - spoon thick liquid (regime/therapy)

designation.value: Dietary liquid consistency - spoon thick liquid (regime/therapy)
Dietary liquid consistency - spoon thick liquid
Liquids included in the diet are provided at a viscosity of > 1750 centipoise (cP). (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).
Decrease in fluid content of the diet compared to the assessed baseline intake of fluid for the individual.
Increase in fluid content of the diet compared to the assessed baseline intake of fluid for the individual.
Liquids included in the diet are provided at a viscosity of 1-50 centipoise (cP). (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).

Replace very hard, sticky or crunchy foods with those that are soft and moist. Treatment for dental problems and mouth soreness. (Source: Nutrition Care Manual, Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics 2013).
Replace normal consistency foods with those that are blended, chopped, ground or mashed so that they are easy to chew and swallow. Treatment for chewing and swallowing problems.
Replace normal consistency foods with those that are blended, whipped or mashed to a "pudding-like" texture. Treatment for chewing and swallowing problems.
